ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the phylogeny and taxonomy of birds.
I learned a LOT about modern bird phylogeny. This class was, "Oh you like birds? Name every bird." Was this useful in any way? Unclear.

I learned a lot about various families of birds and their features, not to mention their relatedness on the phylogenetic tree. While I probably cannot identify an individual species outside of the ones frequently mentioned, I feel that I have a better grasp on bird niches and the variety of birds that exist.
I have learned more about bird ecology than I had ever known before. I can identify birds that I see much easier now.
I learned a lot about the diversity of birds in the world and their evolutionary relationships.
Learned how to identify and more comfortably talk about different birds and taxonomy.
Learned phylogeny of birds, was a great supplement to the lecture. The lab allows you to go much deeper into behavior, systematics, and anatomy of birds.

This course was a valuable counterpart to the lecture section of the course. While the lecture focused more on the phenotype of birds in general, the lab delved into the extensive diversity of modern birds and their taxonomy. While reviewing the phylogeny, we were also introduced to unique aspects of specific birds, allowing us to apply lecture content to specific species.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is very comprehensive. However, it relies on a particular analysis of the phylogeny, which is now out of date (2015). Students should know that the relationships between orders and families are still under discussion.

Strengths: paper discussions were interesting, oral exams were a fun way to assess your knowledge
Weaknesses: memorizing the entire bird phylogeny was not what I realized this course was going to be about and just felt kind of pointless

Strengths: Professor Prum is super passionate about his research, and you can tell just how much he loves talking about birds. He was a real delight. I also felt that the assigned papers (3 in total) were valuable in helping us learn about a more specific group of birds and ecosystems. 

Weaknesses: Because of the virtual format of the lab, it turned into a 3-hour long lecture on bird families once a week, and for that reason, I lost interest in the class at around the hour mark every Tuesday. Further, Prof. Prum's slides could be more conducive to learning in a virtual environment. I understand why he didn't record lectures (as it is a lab!) but the slides were never posted and often the only cue that he had moved on to another order or family of birds was verbal. This was difficult, especially when my Zoom would cut out or if I got distracted for a moment or two. I could never regroup.

Of course, with Covid, it was difficult to hold the same quality of lab over Zoom. Professor Prum did his best to give us a good lab experience, but normally we would see bird skeletons and bones in person in order to learn about their bodies better.
This course was interesting. The lectures were engaging though sometimes ran too long. I wish we would have done more of the literature discussions in class.

The class was interesting and the bird walks informative, but it would  benefit from not being over the zoom format.  Also, oral exams can be very difficult for people with intense social anxiety or just anxiety in general, so those were a weakness of the course in my eyes.

This class was very rich and I loved the lectures. The main problem I had was the workload. Having 3 essays and 2 oral exams for a 0.5 credit course is A LOT of work. The lab is way more work than the lecture, and should be worth 1 credit for the workload. Because we were virtual this semester, we were at a disadvantage because we could  not study the birds in person. Despite this, we had to memorize every bird family (there were over a hundred) which was a lot of work, especially if E&EB is not your major and you're just taking the class for fun.

I understand that the covid version of this class was very different from the way it was intended to be. For what it was, the class was very fast paced which forced us to be engaged, but generated substantial fatigue. I had no issue with this, as I found the content very interesting, but I could see myself being less receptive to information towards the end of each class. The assignments were distributed quite well in that I felt like the work was constant but bearable if I allowed multiple days to prepare for each of them. They were definitely well thought out too, as they encouraged us to do more reading into the topics we found interesting. Still, three papers combined with the term paper for the lecture course amounted to far more writing than I've completed in my WR courses. The oral exams were a clear strength of the class, as they allowed us to more accurately reflect the breadth of information we've retained. For example, even if we forgot the scientific name of a bird family, we could at least be given the chance to show that we known the common name and their placement on the phylogeny.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It would have been great to see specimens even over video during class, in order to get a better understanding of what everything looks like in relation to each other.
I'm pretty sure the entire concept of the lab is different in non-COVID times. I didn't expect it to be so different and this version was not what I hoped for.

I think making the slides more accessible for students, either by posting them afterward or by clearly indicating what we are discussing (the family, order, species, etc). 

If the class stays online, it would also be great to have a more interactive part of the lab, like a birding journal as was mentioned at the beginning of the semester.
The course was fun and the lectures translated online well enough. I think that it would have been better to have 3 oral exams instead of two so the content was broken up into more manageable chunks.
The course struggled with adapting its initial materials, so it was very different than it would have seemed to be in person.

I feel that this class over-compensated for COVID by assigning more work. Assigning 3 essays in a half credit course is a lot, and I'm not sure if we would have had to do that in-person. The oral exams were difficult and made me extremely nervous (flunking is one thing, but flunking real-time in front of your disappointed professor is another). I would have preferred quizzes that were less memory-based. Memorizing the scientific names of 100 families of birds in order doesn't reflect how well you know the material, just how good you are at brute memorization.

Not having any specimens to view did take away from the engagement of the course, but Dr. Prum made up for this with some very engaging content. There was also the potential for some great discussions of lab papers which, when the discussion picked up, added a much needed social component of the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is very comprehensive. However, it relies on a particular analysis of the phylogeny, which is now out of date (2015). Students should know that the relationships between orders and families are still under discussion. Also, memorizing the entire phylogeny is difficult and not necessarily something you need to do or know unless you're planning to work in ornithology, so keep in mind that that is the majority of the work you'll be doing in class.

I wouldn't recommend it in its current format. I was excited to learn about bird morphology and be able to identify birds from specimens, but instead the entire class was memorizing the (not universally accepted) extant bird phylogeny. Though I learned some interesting facts, this class was overall definitely not worth it.
In its current virtual iteration, no. Please take this course in person; it will be a lot more fun.
I would if they are interested in animal ecology. I think they should take it when it is back in-person, however. It would be a great experience to see what were learning up close.
Yes
Yes, very fun course!

I speak purely for the covid version of this class when I say yes but only if you truly enjoy birds. If you are a birder or would like to be able to start identifying the birds around you I would even go as far as saying that this class is essential. While you'll be able to name about 150 bird families and provide some background about each of them by the end, this comes through a whole lot of absorbing lectures, note taking, and memorization.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No other modes.
I guess this is technically a virtual lab, but it was just another virtual lecture. There was some virtual discussion as well.
Virtual lab but largely lecture with a few optional opportunities to go birding.
Safe, in-person bird-watching events for those in New Haven.
Optional walks to watch birds
Occasional bird watching field trips in East Rock
